node.text:
These families… they’re unbelievable. Nobody signs up for this role. This is not a situation that anybody wants.

And yet over and over again, you find the people who history or fate drags out of their lives and throws in front of these cameras and throws in front of these congressional hearings are just beautiful people.

It just speaks to the humanity of the folks who are not famous, or not rich, or not powerful, who don't get a chance to write the laws or make the media happen. There's so much beauty and dignity in this country.

And people shouldn't have to go through this. They shouldn't have to go through this.

And if people ARE going to go through this, and they can reach down and find the kind of humanity that she just showed, and stick up for the best in him and the best in her hometown, then the lawmakers need to do the same damn thing.

You know, it doesn't make sense to be a year out, and we still don't have any real progress.

I appreciate the leadership of, you know, Tim Scott in the Senate along with Cory Booker. I appreciate everything that Karen Bass is trying to do.

But honestly, law enforcement should come forward now. McConnell — all the other people who have as much or more power – to say, “let's just get this done.”

There's so much that people already agree on. The chokehold shouldn’t be happening. The no-knock warrant shouldn’t be happening. So much stuff that we can agree on.

Honor these families. Don't make them go through months, and months, and months of this.

It's just unbelievable to me.

#georgefloyd #policereform

node.title: Nobody signs up for this role.

node.text: Thank you, @theellenshow, for having me on today to talk about #TheFirstStep — a documentary about what it took (behind the scenes) to unite both parties to pass landmark criminal justice reform -- in the middle of the Trump era. The bipartisan bill (FIRST STEP Act) has already freed thousands of people. But nobody knows the real story about how it got done. There are only 1,000 tickets available for the virtual world premiere at @Tribeca — get yours TODAY at TheFirstStep.com #Tribeca2021

node.title: THE FIRST STEP: Virtual World Premiere @tribeca

node.text: Every FOUR MINUTES, someone is reincarcerated for a probation or parole violation. We need #reform. Please watch & share this video and join @REFORM to help change the system and give life back.

node.text:
I was 22. I was in law school. They were teaching me about liberty and justice for all. And I look at TV, and I can't see it. I walk out the front door at Yale Law School, I can't see it.

Literally a few blocks away from the campus, there were kids going to prison for drugs. Kids at Yale were doing drugs all the time – nobody ever called the cops.

Rodney King changed the entire trajectory of my life. I spent the next ten years of my life working on police issues, youth violence issues – and I couldn't believe what I saw.

Had we gotten a positive, fair verdict almost 30 years ago with #RodneyKing, my life would have been different.

You don't understand how it feels when a generation thinks “my life doesn't matter. Anything can happen to me. I could be beaten like Rodney King, nothing would be done.”

You feel totally vulnerable. You don't feel like you're a part of society. I had a law degree, and I felt like an outsider in my own country.

With #GeorgeFloyd, we had a whole generation looking over that cliff at an even bigger scale. Instead, this generation can say “I can make the system work for me.”

The country was just at a crossroads like you can't understand. The humanity of a GENERATION was on trial. Not just a system – the humanity of a whole generation.

And they now see – “I can make the system work for me. It's not fair. I've got to fight harder than I should, but I've got a shot.”

We didn't feel that way in the 90s as young Black folks. We felt like we had been thrown away.

So, this is a big deal. I can't tell you what a big deal this is – for me to be able to look at my sons and tell them, “hey, look guys. It's been this way and worse, but you've got a way forward. Keep fighting, you've got a way forward.”

The arc of the moral universe bends towards justice – if we bend it. 

We gotta fight for it. Hey, but guess what? Sometimes when we fight, we win.

#BlackLivesMatter #JusticeForGeorgeFloyd

node.text:
One down, many, many more to go. This verdict took too much marching — and too many tears. Even with all this evidence, people woke up this morning afraid to hope. 

The message here: we must get more involved like the girl who held the camera. This should never happen again. We need change.

#JusticeForGeorgeFloyd #PoliceBrutality #PoliceReform #DerekChauvin #Guilty

node.text:
As we await a verdict in this horrific case, please stop what you're doing and take time to watch this video. 

I am sure many more media attacks will come down on Black Lives Matter - especially in the coming days. Before that happens, please watch this case study in how a principled, high-integrity leader addresses a bogus, trumped up, ridiculous controversy — with grace, integrity and strength. @osopepatrisse (who is cofounder of Black Lives Matter) does an excellent job of addressing the racism and sexism that is obvious in these bullsh*t attacks on her. She is fully transparent, invites constructive criticism AND humanizes herself in the process. PLEASE watch this.

And then let’s double down on the support of her and the organization she leads.

Along with millions of others, I recognize Patrisse Cullors as one of the new century’s most consequential leaders. I have tried to keep my peace, but I just can’t anymore.

So let me say this: WE ARE DONE OFFERING UP MARTYRS TO MAKE AMERICA BETTER. Black leaders should be able to rise, flourish and prosper while doing the important work of saving America – just like every other kind of leader does. 

Nobody is asking the Kennedys to move out of their compound.

For centuries, Black people were expected to do the hardest work for literally no pay at all. In the last century, every Black leader was expected to be beaten, jailed, and even shot just to advance the cause of democracy. 

So it may take some people a while to get used to the idea that a black person can contribute —without having to be miserable, impoverished, hounded, or killed. But that's what freedom IS. That's what equality MEANS. That's what justice REQUIRES. Our leaders get to make their contribution AND THEY ALSO get to lead full, joyful, complete lives too – just like everybody else.

I want to stress that Patrisse doesn't even take a salary from BLM for her work. That is because she has so much talent in other areas that she can make her living in other ways. But even if she drew a salary, there is nothing wrong with that. The work that Patrisse and other Black women do is invaluable. (More in comments below.)

node.text:
Just say this:
The reason we have police officers is to show up when people are making bad decisions. That's their job. What you want is then for the police officers to make GOOD decisions.

You don't get a great society when you got some people without uniforms making bad decisions, and the people WITH the uniforms making WORSE decisions.

RADICAL IDEA: the police should obey the law.

Excessive force is the only legal concept you don't have to go to law school understand. Force in excess of what you need to do to effect the arrest is excessive force.

And if when somebody is down and they're handcuffed, and they're crying for their mom, and they’re peeing on themselves… if an officer continues applying brutal force against them – that's excessive.

You don't have to be a liberal. You don't have to be a bleeding heart. You just have to be somebody who respects the rule of law and respects that badge to say:

“We don't want people with badges acting that way against anybody, and certainly not given this incredibly bad history with Black folks.”

#BlackLivesMatter #BLM #DerekChauvin #ChauvinTrial #ExcessiveForce #PoliceBrutality #PoliceReform #CJReform @CNN @chrisccuomo

node.text:
Most Black folks walk around with a kind of survivor's guilt because we've seen so many people who look just like us NOT get a break.

When I was at Yale, taught at Princeton, and was at MIT as a fellow I saw white kids do terrible stuff every damn day. I saw white kids on drugs. I saw white kids who were disrespectful. I saw a frat boys doing stuff that would make a gang member ashamed in terms of the level of disrespect and disregard.

The cops were never called on a single one of those kids. Those kids got the benefit of the doubt. They got a second chance. A third chance. A fifteenth chance. And those kids are out having good lives.

And yet blocks away from some of those campuses in the housing projects there are kids doing less-bad stuff getting 15, 20 years in jail or winding up killed. Sometimes by each other.

And you walk around as a Black person with a constant sense of both dread and guilt. “Am I doing enough for my community? Am I doing enough to help?”

I've also spent a lot of time in prisons helping folks. When you go into a prison, it's wall-to-wall African-American men, Latino men. And let's be honest: some of these guys are smarter than me and you. They're better leaders. They're better looking. They made the same mistakes as kids on Ivy League campuses, but they're never going to be able to come out here and compete in the job market. They're not going to be able to be the dads they want to be. And you live with this every day.

And then something like this happens. You saw a grandfather just break down and cry. Because... what are we supposed to do? How can we live? And this Grandpa was tough on George Floyd when George Floyd was acting up, telling him “hey, back down, do what the cops say.” But then he saw him falling, and he saw him dying, and he did his best. And he feels his best was not enough.

Most Black people feel that way every day. That our best is not enough for our communities. It's not enough for the country. It's just not enough.

There’s a lot at stake here. I don’t care who you voted for in the last election — understand the HUMANITY of what’s going on for people every day in this country. We can learn from each other.

node.text: When black folks follow the rules and win elections, right-wing politicians refuse to accept the outcome — and then change the rules. If this jury now says that police can choke black men to death in broad daylight, where does that leave us? The system is failing us, and anything we do to fix it — from sports figures silently “taking a knee” to political leaders like Stacy Abrams mobilizing voters — is deemed unacceptable. If there is no acceptable outlet to reform the system, we are in a very dangerous place. ... We talk about “white rage” and “angry white men.” But some of this “rage” is actually unprocessed grief at the changing of America. Change is inevitable — and hard. Unprocessed grief is very dangerous. There must be a better way forward. History is watching America now — waiting to see if we can make a multiracial democratic republic work in the 21st Century.

node.text: Last year the #AAPI community protested with #BlackLivesMatter. Now we see African Americans from the grassroots to @KingJames & @BarackObama speaking out. Even amidst the heartbreak, the growing solidarity between Black & Asian Americans is a reason to hope.

node.title: Reason to hope: Black & Asian American #Solidarity

node.text: SOMETIMES DREAMS COME TRUE. If a small number of humans can make miracles happen in space, then a large number of humans can make bigger miracles happen here on Earth. I thank God for this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to help leaders across the country do just that. Thank you, @jeffbezos @blueorigin 🚀🚀🚀 #CourageAndCivility

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Van Jones on July 20, 2021 tagging @jeffbezos. May be an image of text that says 'I am beyond honored to accept Jeff Bezos' inaugural Courage & Civility Award. do so with a sense of gratitude, awe and wonder. In my 30 years as an activist and social entrepreneur, have neither heard nor dreamed of a charitable prize of this magnitude.'.

Photo by Van Jones on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Even the award's title both inspires and intimidates. After all, nobody is courageous and kind, 100 percent of the time. get scared and irritable, just like everyone else. But the truth is: the work do has taught me what courage & civility LOOK like and what grace FEELS like.'.
Photo shared by Van Jones on July 20, 2021 tagging @topekaksam, @shakasenghor, @aboveallodds__, @heinspires4real, @dsafavian, @alicemariefree, and @theofficialharryo. May be an image of text.

Photo by Van Jones on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'From prisons, jails and detention centers ...to tough urban neighborhoods to Appalachian coal c”untry.. to Native American reservations ...to the U.S./Mexico border -- see too much genius wasted. have seen too many promising changemakers fail because they could not simultaneously be expert fundraisers.'.

Photo by Van Jones on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'And yet today's escalating social and ecological crises require us to directly empower more visionaries and solutionaries from struggling communities and connect them to the resources and networks they need to thrive. Formerly incarcerated leaders often tell me: "Those closest to the problems are closest to the solutions, but farthest from resources and power."'.

Photo by Van Jones on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I will use this prize to help reverse that sad irony, as best can. Breakthroughs of all kinds are just waiting to be discovered especially at the intersection of advanced technology and community wisdom. When leaders are willing to work together across lines of race and party, they can discover workable solutions to seemingly intractable problems. And when we help grassroots changemakers access (and unleash) the power of technology, finance and media -we can take those innovations powerfully to scale. have seen that process work, using only modest resources. With major resources, the sky is the limit.'.

Photo by Van Jones on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Speaking of that: in this time of challenge and peril, am glad that new astronauts are lifting the ceiling off humanity's dreams, again. inspired whenever someone reaches for the heavens. There is always more heaven up there that the rest of us can reach for each in our am own way.'.

Photo by Van Jones on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If a small number of humans can make miracles happen in space, then a large number of humans can make bigger miracles happen here on Earth. thank God for this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to help leaders across the country do just that.'.

node.text:
These families… they’re unbelievable. Nobody signs up for this role. This is not a situation that anybody wants.

And yet over and over again, you find the people who history or fate drags out of their lives and throws in front of these cameras and throws in front of these congressional hearings are just beautiful people.

It just speaks to the humanity of the folks who are not famous, or not rich, or not powerful, who don't get a chance to write the laws or make the media happen. There's so much beauty and dignity in this country.

And people shouldn't have to go through this. They shouldn't have to go through this.

And if people ARE going to go through this, and they can reach down and find the kind of humanity that she just showed, and stick up for the best in him and the best in her hometown, then the lawmakers need to do the same damn thing.

You know, it doesn't make sense to be a year out, and we still don't have any real progress.

I appreciate the leadership of, you know, Tim Scott in the Senate along with Cory Booker. I appreciate everything that Karen Bass is trying to do.

But honestly, law enforcement should come forward now. McConnell — all the other people who have as much or more power – to say, “let's just get this done.”

There's so much that people already agree on. The chokehold shouldn’t be happening. The no-knock warrant shouldn’t be happening. So much stuff that we can agree on.

Honor these families. Don't make them go through months, and months, and months of this.

It's just unbelievable to me.

#georgefloyd #policereform

node.text: Thank you, @theellenshow, for having me on today to talk about #TheFirstStep — a documentary about what it took (behind the scenes) to unite both parties to pass landmark criminal justice reform -- in the middle of the Trump era. The bipartisan bill (FIRST STEP Act) has already freed thousands of people. But nobody knows the real story about how it got done. There are only 1,000 tickets available for the virtual world premiere at @Tribeca — get yours TODAY at TheFirstStep.com #Tribeca2021

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Van Jones in Tribeca Film Festival with @tribeca. May be an image of 6 people and text.

node.text: One truly beautiful thing happened during the Trump administration. And we filmed it. During the titanic battle to pass bipartisan criminal justice reform, a lot happened behind the scenes that nobody knows about. To learn the truth (good, bad and ugly) about how we freed thousands of people during one of the most divisive moments in American history, get your ticket to watch THE FIRST STEP online for the virtual world premiere @tribeca - TheFirstStep.com #TheFirstStep #Tribeca2021

node.text: Every FOUR MINUTES, someone is reincarcerated for a probation or parole violation. We need #reform. Please watch & share this video and join @REFORM to help change the system and give life back.
